lg.l: Except for those who come to the feet of the Incomparable One,
to dispel the trouble of the mind is hard.

div.p: (i-ḷ). oruvāṟṟāṉun taṉakku nikarillātavaṉatu tāḷaic cērntārk kallatu maṉattiṉkaṇikaḻun tuṉpaṅkaḷai nīkkuta luṇṭākātu, (e-ṟu).

The meaning ... : Removing the sorrows that occur in the mind is impossible (more lit. does not exist) except for those who have united with the feet of the One Who is lacks an equal to Himself in even a single way(?).
“uṟaṟpāla tīṇṭā viṭuta laritu” eṉṟāṟpōla īṇ ṭarumai iṉmaimēṉiṉṟatu. tāḷcērātār piṟivikkētuvākiya kāmavekuḷi mayakkaṅkaḷai māṟṟamāṭṭāmaiyiṉ piṟantiṟan tavaṟṟāṉ varuntuṉpaṅkaḷuḷ aḻuntuva reṉpatām.

Here, as in [the quotation] "... being liberated is difficult," difficulty stands in the sense of impossibility (lit. absence). [This verse?] expresses that those who are not united with [His] feet, [being constantly re]born and dying because they are unable(?) to expel desire, aversion, and delusion, which are the causes of [re]birth, are immersed in the sufferings that come from (lit. through) them [i.e. desire, aversion, and delusion].
i - ḷ:—taṉakku nikarillātāṉatu tiruvaṭiyaic cērntavark kallatu maṉattu uṇṭām kavalaiyai māṟṟutal aritu.
The meaning ... : Apart from those who have united with the feet of Him Who lacks an equal to Himself, it is difficult to expel trouble that arises in the mind.
vīṭupeṟalāvatu, avalak kavalaik kaiyāṟṟiṉ nīṅkip puṇṇiyapāva meṉṉum iraṇṭiṉaiyum cārāmal, cātalum piṟattalumillātatoru taṉmaiyai yeytutal.

The attainment of liberation is (defined as) the attainment of a single nature, without death and rebirth, after one has left behind the helplessness of affliction(s) and(?) trouble(s), without involving oneself in the two, namely good and bad action.
vīṭu peṟumeṉpār muṟpaṭak kavalai keṭumeṉṟār, ataṉāl ellāt tuṉpamum varumātaliṉ.
[The author] will say [further on] that [the devotee?] with obtain liberation; first(?), he has said that [mental] trouble perishes [for him], because all sorrows come from (lit. through) it.
